entries.content: When a meeting feels adversarial or fractured, ask diagnostic questions to understand what's happening.
"It sounds like we're off the wrong tracks here?"
entries.notes: Used to probe when a sales interaction feels like it's going poorly or is fractured.

entries.content: In a fractured situation, pull away; if the prospect genuinely wants to do business, they will often pull you back in.
Be prepared to walk away from a prospect or deal if it's not real or a good fit.
If a prospect doesn't pull you back when you pull away, it tells you all you need to know about the deal's reality.
Overcoming the "need for approval" (fear of pissing off prospects) is crucial for asking tough, diagnostic questions.
Avoiding tough diagnostic questions leads to deals getting stuck in the pipeline's "graveyard of no decision."
Don't fear negative answers from diagnostic questions; they provide necessary clarity on the deal status.
Understand you don't need prospects who aren't going to buy; this empowers you to diagnose disinterest and move on.

focus_area: Handling "Not Interested": Probe softly, diagnose if disinterest or timing
